dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oversized, inefficient planes are the future of aviation? Actually, it's the total opposite—narrowbodies are dominating the recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oversized, inefficient planes are the future of aviation? Actually, it's the total opposite-narrowbodies are dominating the recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aboulafia and Stallard expect Airbus to be cushioned by the popularity of the A321, a long-range narrowbody that can serve as a cheaper alternative to widebodies on thinner long-haul routes, as well as pioneer new ones. He sees demand being hit proportionately harder for the widebodies used on international routes, which are seeing the steepest fall-off in flying, and the 737 MAX: he expects Boeing to deliver just 30 a month of its flagship narrowbody in 2023 and 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners is forecasting airlines will need 6,200 more new aircraft than expected just a few months ago. That's a huge upward revision.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners is forecasting airlines will need six thousand, two hundred more new aircraft than expected just a few months ago. That's a huge upward revision.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he's basing that on a 40% increase in passenger miles this year, which, um, matches IATA's own forecast. Traffic could actually surpass 2018 levels by the end of 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he's basing that on a forty percent increase in passenger miles this year, which, um, matches I A T A's own forecast. Traffic could actually surpass twenty eighteen levels by the end of twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast, and a slow recovery that only sees airline traffic return to 2018 levels in 2026.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—after 9/11, recovery took months for long-haul flights, but analyst Helane Becker thinks this rebound could only take 6 to 12 months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-after nine over eleven, recovery took months for long-haul flights, but analyst Helane Becker thinks this rebound could only take six to twelve months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cowen airline analyst Helane Becker told Forbes she expects it will take 18 to 24 months for traffic to return to some level of normal. After 9/11, it took roughly seven years for U.S. airlines traffic to fully recover on flights over 500 miles and over 1,000 miles, she notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And all that demand is pushing deliveries way up. Stallard expects Airbus to deliver 50% more planes through 2024—that's like an extra 2,000 aircraft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all that demand is pushing deliveries way up. Stallard expects Airbus to deliver fifty percent more planes through twenty twenty four-that's like an extra two thousand aircraft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He expects Airbus deliveries will come in 21% lower than hed previously forecast from 2020 through 2024, off 1,012 planes, while Boeing's will be down 26%, or 931 planes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Boeing's looking at a 60% increase, around 1,000 additional planes. The narrowbody market is just exploding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Boeing's looking at a sixty percent increase, around ten hundred additional planes. The narrowbody market is just exploding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He expects Airbus deliveries will come in 21% lower than hed previously forecast from 2020 through 2024, off 1,012 planes, while Boeing's will be down 26%, or 931 planes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Airbus might even hit a rate of 100 A320-family jets per month by 2022. That's way above their old targets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Airbus might even hit a rate of one hundred A320-family jets per month by twenty twenty two. That's way above their old targets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airbus monthly delivery rate for the A320 family could recover to 55 a month by 2022, Stallard forecasts, eight shy of the planemakers former production goal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, widebody demand isn't growing as fast, which is interesting because international travel is coming back strong too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, widebody demand isn't growing as fast, which is interesting because international travel is coming back strong too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He sees demand being hit proportionately harder for the widebodies used on international routes, which are seeing the steepest fall-off in flying, and the 737 MAX: he expects Boeing to deliver just 30 a month of its flagship narrowbody in 2023 and 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But get this—Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group thinks some forecasts are actually too conservative. He says the peak might hit $250 billion in deliveries by 2022.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But get this-Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group thinks some forecasts are actually too conservative. He says the peak might hit two hundred fifty dollars billion in deliveries by twenty twenty two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This and other estimates may be too conservative, says Richard Aboulafia, Teal Groups vice president of analysis, given the many unknowns as to the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond and the effectiveness of government efforts to support airlines, manufactures and the global economy. I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He's pointing out that there's no government support needed right now because factories are already thriving. They're producing at record pace.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's pointing out that there's no government support needed right now because factories are already thriving. They're producing at record pace.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. and European governments are also lining up to provide financial support that will keep factories open and producing planes that the market doesnt really want right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—Boeing's CEO even said he'd accept federal help if it meant keeping employment high. There's language in the stimulus about maintaining headcount at 150% of current levels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-Boeing's C E O even said he'd accept federal help if it meant keeping employment high. There's language in the stimulus about maintaining headcount at one hundred fifty percent of current levels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing CEO David Calhoun said last week that he wouldnt take federal assistance if it required surrendering equity to the government. Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So they're trying to balance ramping up production with this huge short-term demand, without overcommitting long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they're trying to balance ramping up production with this huge short-term demand, without overcommitting long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both sides need to find a way production can be cut, employee head count can be cut, but some sort of support can be found for keeping production higher than actual short-term market needs, which are approaching zero, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a delicate dance, but honestly? The industry's looking stronger than almost anyone predicted just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a delicate dance, but honestly? The industry's looking stronger than almost anyone predicted just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the coronavirus pandemic ends, many industry watchers now expect it will take years for airlines to return to their former size. Thats a bad scenario for airplane makers and their suppliers.

artist_script:
Oversized, inefficient planes are the future of aviation? Actually, it's the total opposite—narrowbodies are dominating the recovery.
HostB: Yeah, and Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners is forecasting airlines will need 6,200 more new aircraft than expected just a few months ago. That’s a huge upward revision.
HostA: Right, and he’s basing that on a 40% increase in passenger miles this year, which, um, matches IATA’s own forecast. Traffic could actually surpass 2018 levels by the end of 2020.
HostB: It’s wild—after 9/11, recovery took months for long-haul flights, but analyst Helane Becker thinks this rebound could only take 6 to 12 months.
HostA: And all that demand is pushing deliveries way up. Stallard expects Airbus to deliver 50% more planes through 2024—that’s like an extra 2,000 aircraft.
HostB: And Boeing’s looking at a 60% increase, around 1,000 additional planes. The narrowbody market is just exploding.
HostA: Yeah, Airbus might even hit a rate of 100 A320-family jets per month by 2022. That’s way above their old targets.
HostB: Meanwhile, widebody demand isn’t growing as fast, which is interesting because international travel is coming back strong too.
HostA: But get this—Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group thinks some forecasts are actually too conservative. He says the peak might hit $250 billion in deliveries by 2022.
HostB: He’s pointing out that there’s no government support needed right now because factories are already thriving. They’re producing at record pace.
HostA: Exactly—Boeing’s CEO even said he’d accept federal help if it meant keeping employment high. There’s language in the stimulus about maintaining headcount at 150% of current levels.
HostB: So they’re trying to balance ramping up production with this huge short-term demand, without overcommitting long-term.
HostA: It’s a delicate dance, but honestly? The industry’s looking stronger than almost anyone predicted just a few months ago.
